sn55.65:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when four things are developed and cultivated they lead to deep wisdom …”

sn55.66:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when four things are developed and cultivated they lead to extraordinary wisdom …”

sn55.67:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when four things are developed and cultivated they lead to vast wisdom …”

sn55.68:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when four things are developed and cultivated they lead to much wisdom …”

sn55.69:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when four things are developed and cultivated they lead to fast wisdom …”

sn55.7:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena veḷudvāraṃ nāma kosalānaṃ brāhmaṇagāmo tadavasari.
sn55.7:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Bamboo Gate.

sn55.7:1.3.eng: The brahmins and householders of Bamboo Gate heard:

sn55.7:1.4.pli: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ veḷudvāraṃ anuppatto.
sn55.7:1.4.eng: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Bamboo Gate, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.

sn55.7:1.5.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

sn55.7:1.6.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’.
sn55.7:1.6.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

sn55.7:1.7.pli: So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
sn55.7:1.7.eng: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

sn55.7:1.8.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
sn55.7:1.8.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

sn55.7:1.9.pli: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī”ti.
sn55.7:1.9.eng: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

sn55.7:2.1.pli: Atha kho te veḷudvāreyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā appekacce bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu; sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Appekacce bhagavato santike nāmagottaṃ sāvetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te veḷudvāreyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn55.7:2.1.eng: Then the brahmins and householders of Bamboo Gate went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. Seated to one side they said to the Buddha:

sn55.7:2.2.eng: “Worthy Gotama, these are our wishes, desires, and hopes.

sn55.7:2.3.pli: puttasambādhasayanaṃ ajjhāvaseyyāma, kāsikacandanaṃ paccanubhaveyyāma, mālāgandhavilepanaṃ dhāreyyāma, jātarūparajataṃ sādiyeyyāma, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyyāma.
sn55.7:2.3.eng: We wish to live at home with our children; to use sandalwood imported from Kāsi; to wear garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and to accept gold and currency. And when our body breaks up, after death, we wish to be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn55.7:2.4.pli: Tesaṃ no bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ evaṅkāmānaṃ evaṃchandānaṃ evaṃadhippāyānaṃ tathā dhammaṃ desetu yathā mayaṃ puttasambādhasayanaṃ ajjhāvaseyyāma …pe… sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyyāmā”ti.
sn55.7:2.4.eng: Given that we have such wishes, may the Buddha teach us the Dhamma so that we may achieve them.”

sn55.7:3.1.eng: “Householders, I will teach you an explanation of the Dhamma that applies to oneself.

sn55.7:3.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn55.7:3.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn55.7:3.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho te veḷudvāreyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn55.7:4.1.eng: “And what is the explanation of the Dhamma that applies to oneself?

sn55.7:4.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:

sn55.7:4.3.eng: ‘I want to live and don’t want to die; I want to be happy and recoil from pain.

sn55.7:4.4.pli: Yo kho maṃ jīvitukāmaṃ amaritukāmaṃ sukhakāmaṃ dukkhappaṭikūlaṃ jīvitā voropeyya, na metaṃ assa piyaṃ manāpaṃ.
sn55.7:4.4.eng: Since this is so, if someone were to take my life, I wouldn’t like that.

sn55.7:4.5.pli: Ahañceva kho pana paraṃ jīvitukāmaṃ amaritukāmaṃ sukhakāmaṃ dukkhappaṭikūlaṃ jīvitā voropeyyaṃ, parassapi taṃ assa appiyaṃ amanāpaṃ.
sn55.7:4.5.eng: But others also want to live and don’t want to die; they want to be happy and recoil from pain. So if I were to take the life of someone else, they wouldn’t like that either.

sn55.7:4.6.pli: Yo kho myāyaṃ dhammo appiyo amanāpo, parassa peso dhammo appiyo amanāpo.
sn55.7:4.6.eng: The thing that is disliked by me is also disliked by others.

sn55.7:4.7.pli: Yo kho myāyaṃ dhammo appiyo amanāpo, kathāhaṃ paraṃ tena saṃyojeyyan’ti.
sn55.7:4.7.eng: Since I dislike this thing, how can I inflict it on someone else?’

sn55.7:4.8.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya attanā ca pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, parañca pāṇātipātā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, pāṇātipātā veramaṇiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
sn55.7:4.8.eng: Reflecting in this way, they give up killing living creatures themselves. And they encourage others to give up killing living creatures, praising the giving up of killing living creatures.

sn55.7:4.9.eng: So their bodily behavior is purified in three points.

sn55.7:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

sn55.7:5.2.pli: ‘yo kho me adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādiyeyya, na metaṃ assa piyaṃ manāpaṃ.
sn55.7:5.2.eng: ‘If someone were to steal from me, I wouldn’t like that.

sn55.7:5.3.pli: Ahañceva kho pana parassa adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādiyeyyaṃ, parassapi taṃ assa appiyaṃ amanāpaṃ.
sn55.7:5.3.eng: But if I were to steal from someone else, they wouldn’t like that either.

sn55.7:5.4.pli: Yo kho myāyaṃ dhammo appiyo amanāpo, parassa peso dhammo appiyo amanāpo.
sn55.7:5.4.eng: The thing that is disliked by me is also disliked by others.

sn55.7:5.5.pli: Yo kho myāyaṃ dhammo appiyo amanāpo, kathāhaṃ paraṃ tena saṃyojeyyan’ti.
sn55.7:5.5.eng: Since I dislike this thing, how can I inflict it on someone else?’

sn55.7:5.6.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya attanā ca adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, parañca adinnādānā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, adinnādānā veramaṇiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
sn55.7:5.6.eng: Reflecting in this way, they give up stealing themselves. And they encourage others to give up stealing, praising the giving up of stealing.

sn55.7:5.7.eng: So their bodily behavior is purified in three points.

sn55.7:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

sn55.7:6.2.pli: ‘yo kho me dāresu cārittaṃ āpajjeyya, na metaṃ assa piyaṃ manāpaṃ.
sn55.7:6.2.eng: ‘If someone were to have sexual relations with my wives, I wouldn’t like it.

sn55.7:6.3.pli: Ahañceva kho pana parassa dāresu cārittaṃ āpajjeyyaṃ, parassapi taṃ assa appiyaṃ amanāpaṃ.
sn55.7:6.3.eng: But if I were to have sexual relations with someone else’s wives, he wouldn’t like that either.

sn55.7:6.4.pli: Yo kho myāyaṃ dhammo appiyo amanāpo, parassa peso dhammo appiyo amanāpo.
sn55.7:6.4.eng: The thing that is disliked by me is also disliked by others.

sn55.7:6.5.pli: Yo kho myāyaṃ dhammo appiyo amanāpo, kathāhaṃ paraṃ tena saṃyojeyyan’ti.
sn55.7:6.5.eng: Since I dislike this thing, how can I inflict it on others?’

sn55.7:6.6.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya attanā ca kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, parañca kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
sn55.7:6.6.eng: Reflecting in this way, they give up sexual misconduct themselves. And they encourage others to give up sexual misconduct, praising the giving up of sexual misconduct.

sn55.7:6.7.eng: So their bodily behavior is purified in three points.

sn55.7:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

sn55.7:7.2.pli: ‘yo kho me musāvādena atthaṃ bhañjeyya, na metaṃ assa piyaṃ manāpaṃ.
sn55.7:7.2.eng: ‘If someone were to distort my meaning by lying, I wouldn’t like it.

sn55.7:7.3.pli: Ahañceva kho pana parassa musāvādena atthaṃ bhañjeyyaṃ, parassapi taṃ assa appiyaṃ amanāpaṃ.
sn55.7:7.3.eng: But if I were to distort someone else’s meaning by lying, they wouldn’t like it either.

sn55.7:7.4.pli: Yo kho myāyaṃ dhammo appiyo amanāpo, parassa peso dhammo appiyo amanāpo.
sn55.7:7.4.eng: The thing that is disliked by me is also disliked by someone else.

sn55.7:7.5.pli: Yo kho myāyaṃ dhammo appiyo amanāpo, kathāhaṃ paraṃ tena saṃyojeyyan’ti.
sn55.7:7.5.eng: Since I dislike this thing, how can I inflict it on others?’

sn55.7:7.6.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya attanā ca musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, parañca musāvādā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, musāvādā veramaṇiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
sn55.7:7.6.eng: Reflecting in this way, they give up lying themselves. And they encourage others to give up lying, praising the giving up of lying.

sn55.7:7.7.eng: So their verbal behavior is purified in three points.

sn55.7:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

sn55.7:8.2.pli: “yo kho maṃ pisuṇāya vācāya mitte bhindeyya, na metaṃ assa piyaṃ manāpaṃ.
sn55.7:8.2.eng: ‘If someone were to break me up from my friends by divisive speech, I wouldn’t like it.

sn55.7:8.3.pli: Ahañceva kho pana paraṃ pisuṇāya vācāya mitte bhindeyyaṃ, parassapi taṃ assa appiyaṃ amanāpaṃ …pe…
sn55.7:8.3.eng: But if I were to break someone else from their friends by divisive speech, they wouldn’t like it either. …’

sn55.7:8.4.eng: So their verbal behavior is purified in three points.

sn55.7:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

sn55.7:9.2.pli: “yo kho maṃ pharusāya vācāya samudācareyya, na metaṃ assa piyaṃ manāpaṃ.
sn55.7:9.2.eng: ‘If someone were to attack me with harsh speech, I wouldn’t like it.

sn55.7:9.3.pli: Ahañceva kho pana paraṃ pharusāya vācāya samudācareyyaṃ, parassapi taṃ assa appiyaṃ amanāpaṃ.
sn55.7:9.3.eng: But if I were to attack someone else with harsh speech, they wouldn’t like it either. …’

sn55.7:9.5.eng: So their verbal behavior is purified in three points.

sn55.7:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:

sn55.7:10.2.pli: ‘yo kho maṃ samphabhāsena samphappalāpabhāsena samudācareyya, na metaṃ assa piyaṃ manāpaṃ.
sn55.7:10.2.eng: ‘If someone were to annoy me by talking silliness and nonsense, I wouldn’t like it.

sn55.7:10.3.pli: Ahañceva kho pana paraṃ samphabhāsena samphappalāpabhāsena samudācareyyaṃ, parassapi taṃ assa appiyaṃ amanāpaṃ.
sn55.7:10.3.eng: But if I were to annoy someone else by talking silliness and nonsense, they wouldn’t like it either.’

sn55.7:10.4.pli: Yo kho myāyaṃ dhammo appiyo amanāpo, parassa peso dhammo appiyo amanāpo.
sn55.7:10.4.eng: The thing that is disliked by me is also disliked by another.

sn55.7:10.5.pli: Yo kho myāyaṃ dhammo appiyo amanāpo, kathāhaṃ paraṃ tena saṃyojeyyan’ti.
sn55.7:10.5.eng: Since I dislike this thing, how can I inflict it on another?’

sn55.7:10.6.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya attanā ca samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti, parañca samphappalāpā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, samphappalāpā veramaṇiyā ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
sn55.7:10.6.eng: Reflecting in this way, they give up talking nonsense themselves. And they encourage others to give up talking nonsense, praising the giving up of talking nonsense.

sn55.7:10.7.eng: So their verbal behavior is purified in three points.

sn55.7:11.1.eng: And they have experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.7:11.2.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti;

sn55.7:11.4.pli: saṅghe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassāti.

sn55.7:11.5.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.7:11.5.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.7:11.6.pli: Yato kho, gahapatayo, ariyasāvako imehi sattahi saddhammehi samannāgato hoti imehi catūhi ākaṅkhiyehi ṭhānehi, so ākaṅkhamāno attanāva attānaṃ byākareyya:
sn55.7:11.6.eng: When a noble disciple possesses these seven good qualities and these four desirable states they may, if they wish, declare of themselves:

sn55.7:11.7.pli: ‘khīṇanirayomhi khīṇatiracchānayoni khīṇapettivisayo khīṇāpāyaduggativinipāto, sotāpannohamasmi avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo’”ti.
sn55.7:11.7.eng: ‘I’ve finished with rebirth in hell, the animal realm, and the ghost realm. I’ve finished with all places of loss, bad places, the underworld. I am a stream-enterer! I’m not liable to be reborn in the underworld, and am destined for awakening.’”

sn55.7:12.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, veḷudvāreyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn55.7:12.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Bamboo Gate said to the Buddha,

sn55.7:12.3.pli: ete mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
sn55.7:12.3.eng: We go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn55.7:12.4.pli: Upāsake no bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇaṃ gate”ti.
sn55.7:12.4.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”

sn55.70:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when four things are developed and cultivated they lead to light wisdom …”

sn55.71:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when four things are developed and cultivated they lead to laughing wisdom …”

sn55.72:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when four things are developed and cultivated they lead to swift wisdom …”

sn55.73:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when four things are developed and cultivated they lead to sharp wisdom …”

sn55.74:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when four things are developed and cultivated they lead to penetrating wisdom.

sn55.74:1.3.eng: Associating with true persons, listening to the true teaching, rational application of mind, and practicing in line with the teaching.

sn55.74:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā nibbedhikapaññatāya saṃvattantī”ti.
sn55.74:1.4.eng: When these four things are developed and cultivated they lead to penetrating wisdom.”

sn55.74:2.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on Stream-Entry, the eleventh section.

sn55.8:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā ñātike viharati giñjakāvasathe.
sn55.8:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Ñātika in the brick house.

sn55.8:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn55.8:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn55.8:2.1.eng: “Sir, the monk named Sāḷha has passed away.

sn55.8:2.2.eng: Where has he been reborn in his next life?

sn55.8:2.7.eng: and the laywoman named Sujātā have passed away.

sn55.8:2.8.eng: Where have they been reborn in the next life?”

sn55.8:3.1.pli: “Sāḷho, ānanda, bhikkhu kālaṅkato āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
sn55.8:3.1.eng: “Ānanda, the monk Sāḷha passed away having realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.

sn55.8:3.2.pli: Nandā, ānanda, bhikkhunī kālaṅkatā pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātikā tattha parinibbāyinī anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā.
sn55.8:3.2.eng: The nun Nandā passed away having ended the five lower fetters. She’s been reborn spontaneously, and will be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.

sn55.8:3.3.pli: Sudatto, ānanda, upāsako kālaṅkato tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmī; sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karissati.
sn55.8:3.3.eng: The layman Sudatta passed away having ended three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion. He’s a once-returner; he will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

sn55.8:3.4.pli: Sujātā, ānanda, upāsikā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā.
sn55.8:3.4.eng: The laywoman Sujātā passed away having ended three fetters. She’s a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.8:4.1.pli: Anacchariyaṃ kho panetaṃ, ānanda, yaṃ manussabhūto kālaṃ kareyya;
sn55.8:4.1.eng: It’s no wonder that a human being should pass away.

sn55.8:4.2.pli: tasmiṃ tasmiñce maṃ kālaṅkate upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ paṭipucchissatha. Vihesā pesā, ānanda, assa tathāgatassa.
sn55.8:4.2.eng: But if you should come and ask me about it each and every time someone dies that would be a bother for me.

sn55.8:4.3.pli: Tasmātihānanda, dhammādāsaṃ nāma dhammapariyāyaṃ desessāmi; yena samannāgato ariyasāvako ākaṅkhamāno attanāva attānaṃ byākareyya:
sn55.8:4.3.eng: So Ānanda, I will teach you the explanation of the Dhamma named ‘the mirror of the teaching’. A noble disciple who has this may declare of themselves:

sn55.8:4.4.pli: ‘khīṇanirayomhi khīṇatiracchānayoni khīṇapettivisayo khīṇāpāyaduggativinipāto, sotāpannohamasmi avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo’.
sn55.8:4.4.eng: ‘I’ve finished with rebirth in hell, the animal realm, and the ghost realm. I’ve finished with all places of loss, bad places, the underworld. I am a stream-enterer! I’m not liable to be reborn in the underworld, and am destined for awakening.’

sn55.8:5.1.pli: Katamo ca so, ānanda, dhammādāso dhammapariyāyo; yena samannāgato ariyasāvako ākaṅkhamāno attanāva attānaṃ byākareyya:
sn55.8:5.1.eng: And what is that mirror of the teaching?

sn55.8:5.2.pli: ‘khīṇanirayomhi khīṇatiracchānayoni khīṇapettivisayo khīṇāpāyaduggativinipāto, sotāpannohamasmi avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo’?

sn55.8:6.1.pli: Idha, ānanda, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
sn55.8:6.1.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.8:6.4.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.8:6.4.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.8:6.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho so, ānanda, dhammādāso dhammapariyāyo;
sn55.8:6.5.eng: This is that mirror of the teaching.

sn55.8:6.6.pli: yena samannāgato ariyasāvako ākaṅkhamāno attanāva attānaṃ byākareyya:
sn55.8:6.6.eng: A noble disciple who has this may declare of themselves:

sn55.8:6.7.pli: ‘khīṇanirayomhi khīṇatiracchānayoni khīṇapettivisayo khīṇāpāyaduggativinipāto, sotāpannohamasmi avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo’”ti.
sn55.8:6.7.eng: ‘I’ve finished with rebirth in hell, the animal realm, and the ghost realm. I’ve finished with all places of loss, bad places, the underworld. I am a stream-enterer! I’m not liable to be reborn in the underworld, and am destined for awakening.’”

sn55.8:6.9.eng: (The following two discourses have the same setting.)

sn55.9:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn55.9:1.2.eng: “Sir, the monk named Asoka has passed away.

sn55.9:1.3.eng: Where has he been reborn in his next life?

sn55.9:1.6.eng: and the laywoman named Asokā have passed away.

sn55.9:1.7.eng: Where have they been reborn in the next life?”

sn55.9:2.1.pli: “Asoko, ānanda, bhikkhu kālaṅkato āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi …pe…
sn55.9:2.1.eng: “Ānanda, the monk Asoka passed away having realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life …

sn55.9:2.2.eng: (And all is explained as in SN 55.8.)

sn55.9:3.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho so, ānanda, dhammādāso dhammapariyāyo;
sn55.9:3.1.eng: This is that mirror of the teaching.

sn55.9:3.2.pli: yena samannāgato ariyasāvako ākaṅkhamāno attanāva attānaṃ byākareyya:
sn55.9:3.2.eng: A noble disciple who has this may declare of themselves:

sn55.9:3.3.pli: ‘khīṇanirayomhi khīṇatiracchānayoni khīṇapettivisayo khīṇāpāyaduggativinipāto, sotāpannohamasmi avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo’”ti.
sn55.9:3.3.eng: ‘I’ve finished with rebirth in hell, the animal realm, and the ghost realm. I’ve finished with all places of loss, bad places, the underworld. I am a stream-enterer! I’m not liable to be reborn in the underworld, and am destined for awakening.’”

sn56.1:1.4.eng: A mendicant who has immersion truly understands.

sn56.1:1.6.pli: ‘Idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn56.1:1.6.eng: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

sn56.1:1.8.eng: A mendicant who has immersion truly understands.

sn56.1:2.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yogo karaṇīyo, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yogo karaṇīyo, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.1:2.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation to understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.”

sn56.10:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, don’t engage in all kinds of low talk, such as

sn56.10:1.2.pli: rājakathaṃ corakathaṃ mahāmattakathaṃ senākathaṃ, bhayakathaṃ yuddhakathaṃ, annakathaṃ pānakathaṃ vatthakathaṃ sayanakathaṃ mālākathaṃ gandhakathaṃ, ñātikathaṃ yānakathaṃ gāmakathaṃ nigamakathaṃ nagarakathaṃ janapadakathaṃ itthikathaṃ sūrakathaṃ visikhākathaṃ kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṃ, pubbapetakathaṃ nānattakathaṃ, lokakkhāyikaṃ samuddakkhāyikaṃ itibhavābhavakathaṃ iti vā.
sn56.10:1.2.eng: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and talk at the well; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that place.

sn56.10:1.4.pli: Nesā, bhikkhave, kathā atthasaṃhitā nādibrahmacariyakā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati.
sn56.10:1.4.eng: Because those discussions aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn56.10:2.1.pli: Kathentā ca kho tumhe, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti katheyyātha, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti katheyyātha, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti katheyyātha, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti katheyyātha.
sn56.10:2.1.eng: When you discuss, you should discuss: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. …

sn56.10:2.3.pli: Esā, bhikkhave, kathā atthasaṃhitā, esā ādibrahmacariyakā, esā nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.

sn56.10:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
sn56.10:3.1.eng: That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sn56.102:0.3.eng: Passing Away as Humans and Reborn in Hell

sn56.102:1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā parittaṃ nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsuṃ āropetvā bhikkhū āmantesi:

sn56.102:1.2.pli: “taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—

sn56.102:1.3.pli: yo vāyaṃ mayā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito, ayaṃ vā mahāpathavī”ti?

sn56.102:1.6.pli: appamattakāyaṃ bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito.

sn56.102:1.7.pli: Saṅkhampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti mahāpathaviṃ upanidhāya bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito”ti.

sn56.102:1.8.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye manussā cutā manussesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye manussā cutā niraye paccājāyanti …pe….
sn56.102:1.8.eng: “… the sentient beings who die as humans and are reborn as humans are few, while those who die as humans and are reborn in hell are many …”

sn56.103:0.3.eng: Passing Away as Humans and Reborn as Animals

sn56.103:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye manussā cutā manussesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye manussā cutā tiracchānayoniyā paccājāyanti …pe….
sn56.103:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who die as humans and are reborn as humans are few, while those who die as humans and are reborn in the animal realm are many …”

sn56.104:0.3.eng: Passing Away as Humans and Reborn as Ghosts

sn56.104:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye manussā cutā manussesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye manussā cutā pettivisaye paccājāyanti …pe….
sn56.104:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who die as humans and are reborn as humans are few, while those who die as humans and are reborn in the ghost realm are many …”

sn56.105-107:0.3.eng: Passing Away as Humans and Reborn as Gods

sn56.105-107:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye manussā cutā devesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye manussā cutā niraye paccājāyanti …pe… tiracchānayoniyā paccājāyanti …pe… pettivisaye paccājāyanti …pe….
sn56.105-107:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who die as humans and are reborn as gods are few, while those who die as humans and are reborn in hell, or the animal realm, or the ghost realm are many.”

sn56.108-110:0.3.eng: Passing Away as Gods and Reborn as Gods

sn56.108-110:1.1.pli: … “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye devā cutā devesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye devā cutā niraye paccājāyanti …pe… tiracchānayoniyā paccājāyanti …pe… pettivisaye paccājāyanti …pe….
sn56.108-110:1.1.eng: “… the sentient beings who die as gods and are reborn as gods are few, while those who die as gods and are reborn in hell, or the animal realm, or the ghost realm are many.”
